article_content:
**House Passes 'One Big Beautiful Bill Act' Reducing Taxes and Altering Spending**

The House Budget Committee has approved the "One Big Beautiful Bill Act", Public Law No. 119-21, which reduces taxes and alters spending for various federal programs. The bill also increases the statutory debt limit. [https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/house-bill/1](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/house-bill/1)

Rep. Jodey C. Arrington (R-VA), the sponsor of the bill, [https://www.congress.gov/member/rep-arrington-jodey-c/A000375](https://www.congress.gov/member/rep-arrington-jodey-c/A000375) introduced the legislation.  The bill passed the House with a party-line vote of 218 to 2, with Republicans voting in favor and Democrats voting against. [House Roll Call 190](https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/house-bill/3)

The bill has been referred to the House Budget Committee.  [https://www.congress.gov/committee/house-budget-committee/hsbu00](https://www.congress.gov/committee/house-budget-committee/hsbu00) The "One Big Beautiful Bill Act" was passed on July 4, 2025 and has been subject to 493 amendments.  Senators Padilla, Alex [D-CA] proposed amendments SAMDT 2851 and SAMDT 2850. Senator Klobuchar, Amy [D-MN] proposed amendment SAMDT 2849 to strike a provision relating to delayed implementation of the supplemental nutrition assistance program matching funds requirements. Senator Graham, Lindsey [R-SC] proposed amendment SAMDT 2848 to improve the bill.  Senator Warner, Mark R. [D-VA] proposed amendment SAMDT 2847 to use revenues from lease payments from Metropolitan Washington Airports for aviation safety improvements and other purposes.

**Senate Approves Continuing Appropriations Bill, HR.5371**

The Senate voted 54-45 on a motion to proceed to the Continuing Appropriations and Extensions Act of 2026, also known as HR.5371. The bill provides continuing funding for federal agencies in FY2026 [link to bill].  It also includes additional funding for security for federal officials. The bill is currently under consideration by the Senate.

The House Appropriations Committee and the House Budget Committee are responsible for reviewing this legislation. [https://www.congress.gov/committee/house-appropriations-committee/hsap00](https://www.congress.gov/committee/house-appropriations-committee/hsap00) [https://www.congress.gov/committee/house-budget-committee/hsbu00](https://www.congress.gov/committee/house-budget-committee/hsbu00)

Rep. Cole, Tom is the sponsor of the bill. [https://www.congress.gov/member/rep-cole-tom/C001053](https://www.congress.gov/member/rep-cole-tom/C001053) 


No cosponsors have been listed for the bill. The provided text does not contain information about whether any of the cosponsors are members of the committee that the bill is in.  

No hearings have been held on the bill. [https://www.congress.gov/](https://www.congress.gov/) 

No amendments have been proposed to the bill. 
 
The Senate vote occurred with a party-line result, as no detailed party breakdown was available for the vote.  [Record Vote Number: 590](https://www.congress.gov/vote/?id=590)

**House Passes Pay Our Troops Act of 2026 to Guarantee Military Pay During Government Shutdowns**

The House of Representatives has passed the Pay Our Troops Act of 2026, a bill that would provide continuing appropriations for military pay during periods when interim or full-year appropriations for Fiscal Year 2026 are not in effect. This includes situations like government shutdowns. The bill is currently under consideration by the House Committee on Appropriations. [https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/house-bill/5401](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/house-bill/5401)

The bill was introduced by Rep. Kiggans, Jennifer A., and has garnered support from several other members of Congress, including Rep. Fitzpatrick, Brian K., Rep. Mace, Nancy, and Rep. Kean, Thomas H. These lawmakers are all members of the House Committee on Energy and Commerce. [https://www.congress.gov/member/rep-fitzpatrick-brian-k/F000466](https://www.congress.gov/member/rep-fitzpatrick-brian-k/F000466), [https://www.congress.gov/member/rep-mace-nancy/M000194](https://www.congress.gov/member/rep-mace-nancy/M000194) , and [https://www.congress.gov/member/rep-kean-thomas-h/K000398](https://www.congress.gov/member/rep-kean-thomas-h/K000398).  

The bill has yet to be voted on by the full House of Representatives, and no hearings have been scheduled.

bill_title: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2026
article_content:
**Senate Passes National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2026**

The Senate passed the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2026 (S. 2296) on October 9, 2025, with a vote of 77-20. The bill sets forth policies and authorities for the Department of Defense's programs and activities, military construction, and national defense in FY2026. [https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/senate-bill/2296](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/senate-bill/2296)

The bill is currently in the House Armed Services Committee [https://www.congress.gov/committee/house-armed-services-committee/ssas00](https://www.congress.gov/committee/house-armed-services-committee/ssas00).  Sen. Wicker, Roger F. [R-MS] is the sponsor of the bill. [https://www.congress.gov/member/sen-wicker-roger-f/W000437](https://www.congress.gov/member/sen-wicker-roger-f/W000437)

The bill has not yet been assigned to a committee in the House of Representatives, and there are currently no cosponsors listed for it.  [Link to relevant page if one exists] 

Eight hundred eighty-four amendments were proposed on the bill. Amendments SAMDT 3928 and 3927 were proposed by Senators Gallego and Merkley respectively, requiring the Secretary of Defense to establish a pilot program for deploying microreactors and limiting the use of Federal law enforcement officers for crowd control, and for other purposes. [link] Amendment SAMDT 3926 was proposed by Senator Cornyn and aimed at protecting national security by imposing sanctions on certain Chinese individuals and prohibiting anâ€¦  [link]

The bill passed the Senate on October 9, 2025, with a vote of 77 to 20. [Record Vote Number: 570](https://www.congress.gov/vote/570)

bill_title: A bill to designate the facility of the United States Postal Service located at 154 First Avenue East in Jerome, Idaho, as the "Representative Maxine Bell Post Office".
article_content:
**Senate Bill Aims to Rename Post Office After Idaho Representative**

A bill titled "A bill to designate the facility of the United States Postal Service located at 154 First Avenue East in Jerome, Idaho, as the 'Representative Maxine Bell Post Office'", has been introduced in the Senate. The legislation seeks to officially rename the U.S. Postal Service facility at that address as the "Representative Maxine Bell Post Office".  The bill is currently under consideration by the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs. [https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/senate-bill/24](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/senate-bill/24)

The bill's sponsor is Senator Crapo, Mike.  [https://www.congress.gov/member/sen-crapo-mike/C000880](https://www.congress.gov/member/sen-crapo-mike/C000880) 

Senator Risch, James E., [R-ID] (R), has also cosponsored the bill. [https://www.congress.gov/member/sen-risch-james-e/R000584](https://www.congress.gov/member/sen-risch-james-e/R000584) 

The bill is currently in its initial stages of the legislative process and has not yet been subject to hearings or votes. [https://www.congress.gov/](https://www.congress.gov/)

bill_title: Continuing Appropriations and Extensions and Other Matters Act, 2026
article_content:
**Senate Passes Continuing Appropriations Bill, Including Expanded Health Insurance Tax Credit**

The Senate has voted on the Continuing Appropriations and Extensions and Other Matters Act, 2026. The bill provides continuing funding for federal agencies in FY2026 and permanently extends the expanded premium tax credit for health insurance purchases.  The vote was 47 to 50. [Record Vote Number: 557](https://www.congress.gov/vote/557). A detailed party breakdown was not available for the vote. The bill is currently in the process of being debated in the Senate. [https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/senate-bill/2882](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/senate-bill/2882) 
Sen. Murray, Patty is the sponsor of the bill. [https://www.congress.gov/member/sen-murray-patty/M001111](https://www.congress.gov/member/sen-murray-patty/M001111)

**Government Shutdown Prevention Act Advances in Senate**

The Government Shutdown Prevention Act of 2025, which aims to prevent a government shutdown by providing continuing appropriations if an appropriations bill for the fiscal year is not enacted before the start of the fiscal year, has been introduced in the Senate. The bill is currently under review by the Committee on Appropriations. [https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/senate-bill/499](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/senate-bill/499)

The bill is sponsored by Senator Rand Paul, a Republican from Kentucky. [https://www.congress.gov/member/sen-paul-rand/P000603](https://www.congress.gov/member/sen-paul-rand/P000603) 

The bill has no cosponsors listed in the provided text, and there is no information about whether any of the cosponsors are members of the House Appropriations Committee.  No hearings have been scheduled for the bill. [https://www.congress.gov/](https://www.congress.gov/) No amendments have been proposed to the bill.

bill_title: An executive resolution authorizing the en bloc consideration in Executive Session of certain nominations on the Executive Calendar.
article_content:
**Senate Approves Resolution Authorizing En Bloc Consideration of Certain Nominations**

The Senate voted 51-46 on October 3, 2025, to approve a resolution (SRES.412) that authorizes the en bloc consideration of certain nominations on the Executive Calendar in Executive Session. [https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/senate-resolution/412](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/senate-resolution/412) The resolution was agreed to without amendment. 

Sen. Thune, John, is the sponsor of the bill. [https://www.congress.gov/member/sen-thune-john/T000250](https://www.congress.gov/member/sen-thune-john/T000250)  The resolution was passed by a bipartisan vote, but no detailed party breakdown is available.

bill_title: Impeaching Donald John Trump, President of the United States, for high crimes and misdemeanors.
article_content:
**House Judiciary Committee Introduces Resolution to Impeach President Trump**

The House Judiciary Committee has introduced a resolution seeking to impeach President Donald John Trump. The resolution, titled "Impeaching Donald John Trump, President of the United States, for high crimes and misdemeanors," outlines seven articles of impeachment against the president.  The bill is currently in the NOTIFICATION OF INTENT TO OFFER RESOLUTION stage, meaning Rep. Thanedar has notified the House of his intent to offer the resolution. [https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/house-resolution/353](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/house-resolution/353)

The bill is currently under review by the House Judiciary Committee, which has jurisdiction over impeachment proceedings. [https://www.congress.gov/committee/house-judiciary-committee/hsju00](https://www.congress.gov/committee/house-judiciary-committee/hsju00)

Rep. Thanedar, Shri is the sponsor of the bill.  [https://www.congress.gov/member/rep-thanedar-shri/T000488](https://www.congress.gov/member/rep-thanedar-shri/T000488)

Rep. Thanedar's resolution is supported by several other members of the House, including Rep. Mfume, Kweisi [D-MD-7], Rep. Nadler, Jerrold [D-NY-12], and Rep. Kelly, Robin L. [D-IL-2].  Rep. Mfume, Kweisi [D-MD-7] is a member of the House Judiciary Committee. [https://www.congress.gov/member/rep-mfume-kweisi/M000687](https://www.congress.gov/member/rep-mfume-kweisi/M000687)

The bill has not yet been scheduled for hearings or votes.

bill_title: Full-Year Continuing Appropriations and Extensions Act, 2025
article_content:
**House Passes Full-Year Continuing Appropriations and Extensions Act of 2025**

The House Appropriations Committee and the House Budget Committee have enacted the Full-Year Continuing Appropriations and Extensions Act, 2025. The bill was enacted on March 15, 2025 [https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/house-bill/1968](https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/house-bill/1968).  The bill provides continuing FY2025 appropriations for federal agencies and extends various expiring programs and authorities. 

Rep. Cole, Tom is the sponsor of the bill [https://www.congress.gov/member/rep-cole-tom/C001053](https://www.congress.gov/member/rep-cole-tom/C001053).  The bill was passed by a vote of 54 to 46 in the Senate [Record Vote Number: 133](https://www.congress.gov/vote/133). A party-line vote occurred as no detailed party breakdown was available for the Senate votes. 

The bill is currently being considered by the House Appropriations Committee and the House Budget Committee.  [https://www.congress.gov/committee/house-appropriations-committee/hsap00](https://www.congress.gov/committee/house-appropriations-committee/hsap00) [https://www.congress.gov/committee/house-budget-committee/hsbu00](https://www.congress.gov/committee/house-budget-committee/hsbu00).
